## Slide 8: Cardio investment paths: Summary

**Cardio investment paths: Summary**

*   **Strong underlaying cardio macro backdrop:** $50-$60B outpatient TAM with 15-25% growth projected, driven by an inflection point in the nearer term shift to ASCs (fueled by CMS ASC regulations and payer outpatient shifts) and longer-term potential with VBC
*   There are **two main paths for WCAS to invest behind the cardio theme in a scale way: 1) Cardio PPM; 2) ASC JV with health systems;** there is also a potential to pursue a combination of 1 and 2. Enablement models (either payer or provider led) would be another angle to explore that was not part of this investment screen.
*   **PPM and ASC paths both rely on a bet that the platform can team with hospitals who employ 60% of cardiologists** (either directly with a JV, or indirectly via physician co-owners doing procedures at hospitals) as well as the shift of procedures to ASCs
*   **There is path to deploying $250M+ in equity and achieving 3x+ MOICs with both PPM and ASC investments** though there is a wider fan of outcomes for ASCs in the investment horizon given actionability and hospital JV pace; there is more of an open question on PPM white space in the exit horizon
*   **ASC market opportunity is $40B+ TAM with 15-25% growth expected.** There is a chance for WCAS to get in early and quickly become the #1 player in Cardio ASCs, replicating historic success in the ASC space. There are ~150 cardio ASCs today (but only ~30 true cardio) but there is potential 700-850 ASC white space. Challenges include the limited # of starting platforms for M&A and the pace of hospital JV execution.
*   **PPM market opportunity is $10B+ TAM with 12-15% growth projected.** WCAS would enter as the #7 PE-backed platform in the space with ~30 leading pillars to consider (with more of the white space in tuckins) but could potentially leapfrog others with its differentiated PPM track record. Range of value creation levers include classic PPM levers and ancillaries with ASCs a major driver of the upside. Challenges include white space (only 20% of doctors are not hospital employees, 75% of independents in practices <15 docs) and the pace of physician consolidation given income repair considerations
*   **While the near term path to PPM actionability is clearer, WCAS should also explore potential strategic angles to test whether the ASC play is more compelling; Key next steps to test actionability and decide on investment path forward:**
    *   **ASC:** Test strategic angle potential with existing health system partners; test interest in partnering with the top 3-5 ASC targets (e.g. Atlas, National Cardio Partners, Cardiovascular Centers of America, Compass….); note that many of these scale players are jointly pursuing cardio/ortho ASCs
    *   **PPM:** There are ~30 targets that could be the starting pillar of a platform (with ~10 in the most attractive markets); WCAS should also consider the merits of co-investment in one of the current platforms already established
    *   **Markets:** Differentially prioritize markets where both ASC/PPM strategies could be pursued and where WCAS health system partners exists (e.g. Key MSAs in FL, TX)
    *   **Payers:** Pressure test partnership interest with top WCAS strategic payer partners (e.g. ability to replicate a UNH/SCA with one of its payer partners)

## Slide 12: CMS tailwinds: CMS continues to approve more procedures to shift to ASCs; recent approvals introduced interventional cardiology to take place at an ASC

**CMS tailwinds: CMS continues to approve more procedures to shift to ASCs; recent approvals introduced interventional cardiology to take place at an ASC**

**HOPDs are the main site of outpatient cardiovascular procedures, but many have been approved for ASCs; inpatient cardiovascular procedures make up ~50% of the market**

**Inpatient and HOPD cardiovascular charges by billed code (medical and surgical $ reimbursement)**

| Type of procedure                                  | % of Inpatient and HOPD revenue (2021) |
| :------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------- |
| Structural heart procedures (Inpatient)            | ~50%                                   |
| Additional Procedures (HOPD, Not approved)         | 26%                                    |
| Additional Procedures (HOPD, Recently approved since 2018) | 11%                                    |
| Additional Procedures (HOPD, Approved since 2018)  | 3%                                     |
| Additional Procedures (HOPD, Approved since 2020)  | 8%                                     |
| **Total**                                          | **$48B**                               |

**Legend for procedures:**
*   **Electrophysiology:** Comprehensive electrophysiologic study, Electrophysiogram, Transesophageal echocardiogram
*   **Vascular:** Transcatheter closure of structural (atrial) heart defect, Transcatheter implantation of permanent hemodynamic monitor
*   **Interventional cardiology:** Comprehensive electrophysiologic study for the evaluation and ablation of atrial fibrillation (PVI), Transthoracic echocardiogram, Electrocardiogram Tracing, w/o interpretation or report, Cardiac rehabilitation with continuous ECG monitoring, Comprehensive electrophysiologic study for the evaluation and treatment of supraventricular tachycardias, Cardiovascular Stress Test, Transthoracic echocardiogram, at rest and exercise, inclusive of both professional and technical components, Use of external defibrillator to restore regular cardiac rhythm, Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG), Coronary Angiogram, PCI procedures, Stent placement, Valve replacement (TAVR), Mitral Clip, Impella, WATCHMAN, Endovascular aortic repair (EVAR)
*   **Non-invasive:** Diagnostic Cat, Stress Test, Echocardiogram

**In procedure terms, HOPD holds larger market share; inpatient procedures have higher average payments / severity**

**Even though CMS has approved many cardiovascular procedures for ASCs, state regulations present a major barrier**
*   About 230 cardiovascular procedures which take place in HOPDs today have been approved to take place in ASCs as of 2018 (representing ~45% of HOPD charges), ~30 more of these procedures have more recently been approved (~14% of HOPD charges)
    *   Historically low because EP procedures alone were not consistent enough to support ASCs; limited ability to pair with other specialties because PAD often took place in OBL (no need for ASC) and PCI procedures were not approved
    *   Hospitals have been most defensive to move PCI out of hospitals because they are considered to be a cash cow for the hospital (large discrepancy between hospital reimbursement rates vs. ASC reimbursement rates)
*   In addition, certificate-of-need (CON) laws can constrain ASC development and slow the pace of volume shift

"Certificate of need laws are the strongest correlation to the number of ASCs per capita in a state…the certificate of need process requires healthcare providers, including ASCs, to receive state permission to build facilities, make expansions or buy expensive equipment.”
Becker’s Healthcare, Feb. 2022

“About 32 states have CON laws, where hospitals essentially have the power to block ASCs; in states with no CON laws, like AZ, hospitals are being smart and building out their own ASCs to cover themselves against the trend toward outpatient facilities.”
CEO, Competitor #2

Note: HOPD procedures across approval statuses with less than $100M in revenue were combined into the other segments. Excludes IR procedures
Source: Definitive Healthcare data (2020 data for HOPDs); CMS approved procedure lists (2018-2022); Market participant interviews; Becker’s ASC Review

## Slide 13: ASC penetration: Likely to grow from ~10-15% to reach 20-30% by 2026 as more procedures are approved in ASC setting and cardiologists become more comfortable

**ASC penetration: Likely to grow from ~10-15% to reach 20-30% by 2026 as more procedures are approved in ASC setting and cardiologists become more comfortable**

**P R E L I M I N A R Y**

**Top down view suggests ~20-30% procedure penetration**

**Cardiovascular penetration estimates by source (today and in next 5 years)**

| Source                  | OBL/ASC Today | Next 5 years |
| :---------------------- | :------------ | :----------- |
| Physician survey estimates | 10-15%        | 20-30%       |
| Market participants     | 10-15%        | 20-30%       |
| Commercial claims historical trends | 10-15%        | 20-30%       |

**However will vary widely depending on procedure**

**Cardio procedure volume (in 5 years)**

| Procedure type | Performed in OBL/ASC (Range) | Outpatient / Inpatient |
| :------------- | :--------------------------- | :--------------------- |
| EP             | ~20%                         | ~80%                   |
| PCI            | ~20%                         | ~80%                   |
| PAD / other PV | ~60%                         | ~40%                   |

*   **CMS likely to approve more procedures for HOPD setting going forward, representing the first step for other procedures to be approved in OBL/ASC**
    *   Strong lobbying to increase the number of procedures in ASC/OBL; hospitals trying to retain procedures in inpatient setting
*   **Cardiologists becoming more comfortable performing procedures in alternative care settings, and medicine advancing mitigating the risk of complications**

**EP**
*   Recent PCI approvals as well as lower reimbursements for OBLs for PAD is incentivizing proceduralists focused on EP to move to ASCs where the mix can be more than just EP

**PCI**
*   Were only just approved by CMS for reimbursement in 2020, current procedures likely to shift to outpatient (and longer term potential for more procedures to be approved such as multiple stents)

**PAD**
*   High rate of approvals recently. However historically many did not have to take place in cardiovascular ASCs. Changing OBL reimbursements has shifted some to be in ASCs as well as fact many physicians do vascular and PCI

Source: Fair Health; Market participant interviews; Project Cardio Physician Survey (N=213)
